She has no known medical conditions and does not take any medications. The patient appears anxious and says, “I'm starving.” Her temperature is 37.5°C, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 145/82 mmHg. Examination reveals dry mucous membranes and bilateral conjunctival injection. Breath sounds are normal. Further evaluation will most likely reveal which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A sense of closeness to others is not a common feature of cannabis intoxication but may be seen in MDMA intoxication.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased libido is not a common symptom of cannabis intoxication but may be seen in amphetamine intoxication.

C) INCORRECT:

Cannabis intoxication can induce hallucinations. However, tactile hallucinations are more likely to be seen in cocaine intoxication.

D) CORRECT:

The main active ingredient in cannabis is tetrahydrocannabinol, which influences the cannabinoid receptors and can lead to a range of symptoms. One common symptom of cannabis intoxication is impaired reaction time. Additional symptoms include euphoria, social detachment, impaired judgment, mydriasis, perceptual disturbances (e.g., distorted sense of time), and hallucinations.

Key learning point: Cannabis intoxication commonly causes impaired reaction time, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, increased appetite, and perceptual disturbances.

E) INCORRECT:

Cannabis intoxication can cause mydriasis but miosis would be unlikely. However, miosis is often seen in opioid intoxication and phencyclidine intoxication.
questions.hint: This patient's anxiety, vital sign abnormalities (tachycardia, hypertension), dry mouth, conjunctival injection, and increased appetite suggest cannabis intoxication.

questions.text: You are seeing a 15-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic by his mother because of 4 months of unusual behavior. During this time, he has had episodic mood swings. His mother has found him in his room appearing “seemingly drunk” with slurred speech; these episodes last about 15 minutes and are followed by irritability. He has decreased appetite, occasional redness of the eyes, difficulty keeping up with schoolwork, and declining grades. On examination, there is an eczematous rash between his upper lip and nostrils. Neurologic examination reveals a delay in performing alternating palm movements. Use of which one of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cocaine use can cause euphoria and irritability that usually last 15–60 minutes. However, seeming drunk and having slurred speech is not typical for cocaine use. Acute withdrawal symptoms include depression, anxiety, and increased appetite, rather than the irritability seen in this patient. While chronic cocaine use can result in changes in behavior, poor concentration, and decreased appetite, it does not usually cause ataxia. Intranasal cocaine use can cause chronic rhinitis and perforation of the nasal septum; it is not typically associated with a perioral rash.

B) INCORRECT:

Marijuana use can cause slurred speech, conjunctival injection, ataxia, and poor concentration. Acute intoxication often results in euphoria, and withdrawal can cause irritability. However, withdrawal symptoms typically occur several days after abrupt cessation of prolonged marijuana use (not within minutes after use). In addition, marijuana use typically results in increased, not decreased, appetite. Moreover, it is not associated with a perioral rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Phencyclidine (PCP) use can cause neuropsychiatric symptoms, including bizarre behavior, irritability, and ataxia. However, these symptoms typically last for hours; withdrawal symptoms, which can include anxiety and irritability, are not expected within minutes after use. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of PCP intoxication, including diaphoresis, seizures, violent behavior, or hallucinations. Moreover, PCP use is not associated with a perioral rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use, which is common in adolescence, can cause slurred speech, irritability, and ataxia. However, these symptoms typically last for hours; withdrawal symptoms, which can include anxiety, irritability, and anorexia, are not expected within minutes after use. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of alcohol intoxication, such as disinhibited behavior. Moreover, alcohol use is not associated with a perioral rash.

E) CORRECT:

This patient is most likely using inhalants (e.g., aerosols, glue, shoe polish, spray paint), a group of recreational drugs that are most commonly used among adolescents. Common manifestations of inhalant use include mood swings (due to rapid onset and short duration of action), irritability, slurred speech, anorexia, conjunctival injection, poor concentration, ataxia (manifesting as, e.g., dysdiadochokinesia), and an eczematous rash in the perioral area (i.e., the glue-sniffer's rash, which is caused by the drying effects of hydrocarbons), all of which are seen in this patient. In severe cases, inhalant use can cause cardiac arrhythmias and severe central nervous system toxicity (e.g., seizures, coma, and death due to respiratory depression).

Key learning point: Inhalant abuse in adolescents often presents with episodic intoxication, mood swings, perioral eczematous rash, slurred speech, ataxia, and poor concentration due to the rapid onset and short duration of action.
questions.hint: This patient is using a substance that has a mechanism of action that is similar to nitrous oxide; its use results in central nervous system depression that lasts 15–45 minutes.

questions.text: You are seeing a 37-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his coworker because of chest pain that started one hour ago while he was driving. He works as a long-haul truck driver and regularly works night shifts. On arrival, he is extremely agitated. His temperature is 38.9°C, pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 160/102 mm Hg. On examination, his skin is warm and moist, and his pupils are 7 mm bilaterally. Lung auscultation is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is not used to treat amphetamine overdose. Instead, it is used to treat neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) or malignant hyperthermia, which can result in increased body temperature, diaphoresis, tachycardia, hypertension, and an altered mental status. However, NMS typically occurs with antipsychotic medications, and malignant hyperthermia occurs following the administration of volatile anesthetics or muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine. Moreover, the body temperature would usually be extremely high (> 41°C) and mydriasis would not be expected in either of these conditions.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with symptomatic stimulant intoxication (e.g., amphetamine overdose, cocaine overdose) should be treated with benzodiazepines such as diazepam. Benzodiazepines counteract the hyperadrenergic state (e.g., agitation, hypertension) caused by stimulants and prevent seizures. In addition, patients who are actively febrile should be cooled externally.

In patients with symptoms of cardiac ischemia, antihypertensives such as nitroprusside or phentolamine should also be administered if blood pressure does not decrease with the administration of benzodiazepines.

Key learning point: Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment for symptomatic stimulant intoxication.

C) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal is not very useful more than 1–2 hours after the ingestion of a toxic substance. Moreover, activated charcoal requires oral administration, which is generally contraindicated in agitated or drowsy patients due to the risk of aspiration.

D) INCORRECT:

Ketamine is typically used to sedate patients prior to rapid sequence intubation or as an emergency anesthetic for polytrauma patients with risk of hypotension. In this patient, intubation is not indicated at this point in time. Moreover, ketamine can cause further elevation in blood pressure and heart rate and is, therefore, contraindicated in a patient with hypertension and tachycardia.

E) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotics such as haloperidol are generally avoided in patients with stimulant intoxication because they can interfere with heat dissipation, prolong the QTc interval, and possibly decrease the seizure threshold.
questions.hint: Chest pain, diaphoresis, agitation, elevated temperature, tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis suggest the use of stimulants (e.g., amphetamine, cocaine). Some long-haul truck drivers may use stimulants to complete routes that require them to stay awake all night.

questions.text: You are seeing a 20-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by a friend 1 hour after he suddenly became agitated. He reports, "It feels like ants are crawling on my skin." He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His father has hyperthyroidism. His temperature is 37.2°C, pulse is 112/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 145/94 mm Hg. On examination, his skin is warm to the touch and appears normal. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Which one of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute onset of personality and mood changes (e.g., agitation), formication, tachycardia, and hypertension raise suspicion for stimulant intoxication (e.g., from cocaine, amphetamines). Other signs and symptoms of stimulant use include mydriasis, psychomotor agitation, nausea, diaphoresis, loss of appetite, weight loss, and neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., visual and/or auditory hallucinations, delusions). A urine drug screen can confirm intoxication with cocaine and/or amphetamines but it is rarely helpful in the acute management of suspected stimulant intoxication, as false positives can occur due to cross-reactivity with other drugs and/or prolonged excretion of inactive metabolites. Initial management of stimulant intoxication focuses on stabilizing the patient by controlling agitation and the hyperadrenergic state with benzodiazepines and lowering the body temperature. Diagnostic testing is primarily used to assess for alternative diagnoses and/or complications (e.g., ECG to rule out conduction abnormalities and myocardial ischemia).

Bath salt intoxication should be suspected in patients with features of stimulant intoxication but negative urine toxicology.

Key learning point: A urine drug screen is used to confirm stimulant intoxication in patients presenting with acute agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, and formication.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with new-onset psychotic symptoms may require neuroimaging (e.g., CT or MRI of the head) to evaluate for stroke, space-occupying lesions, neurodegenerative brain diseases, and demyelinating disorders, especially if they have concomitant neurological features (e.g., memory loss, headaches, vomiting, seizures, neurological deficits). However, in a young patient who is alert and oriented and has no focal neurological deficits, neurological disease is not the most likely underlying cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Agitation, hallucinations, tachycardia, hypertension, warm skin, and a family history of hyperthyroidism may raise suspicion for hyperthyroidism. However, formication and the acute onset of symptoms make a different underlying condition more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

An ECG should be obtained in all patients presenting with symptoms of stimulant intoxication (e.g., agitation, formication, tachycardia, hypertension) to evaluate for complications of stimulants such as tachyarrhythmia and vasospasm. However, an ECG cannot confirm the diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute onset of hallucinations raises suspicion for a psychotic disorder. However, psychosis is more commonly associated with auditory hallucinations than tactile hallucinations (e.g., formication), which are rare. Moreover, this patient does not display other features of psychosis, such as illusions, delusions, disorganized speech, disorganized behaviors, and negative symptoms. Although individuals with new-onset psychosis may require psychiatric workup, another test is more appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is most likely due to inhibition of dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine reuptake.

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with chest pain and agitation 2 hours after cocaine use. In addition to management of the acute presentation, an evaluation for substance use disorder is initiated. Which of the following domains is not part of the standard assessment to establish the diagnosis according to DSM-5 criteria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired control is one of the four DSM-5 criteria domains for substance use disorder and comprises using substances in larger amounts than intended, repeated failed attempts to cut down, time spent in substance-related activities, and cravings.

B) INCORRECT:

Social impairment is one of the four DSM-5 criteria domains for substance use disorder and encompasses problems fulfilling work, school, family, or social obligations, interpersonal relationship problems, and reduced social, occupational, or recreational activities due to substance use.

C) INCORRECT:

Risky use is one of the four DSM-5 criteria domains for substance use disorder and comprises use in physically hazardous situations and continued use despite awareness of problems related to or exacerbated by substance use.

D) INCORRECT:

Tolerance and/or withdrawal (i.e., pharmacological indicators of substance use) comprise one of the four DSM-5 criteria domains for substance use disorder.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Medical complications are not a separate diagnostic domain in DSM-5 criteria for substance use disorder. While substance use may have medical consequences, the diagnostic criteria focus on behavioral and functional patterns rather than physical health outcomes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the ED with her partner requesting treatment for cocaine use disorder. She reports escalating use over 8 months, spending her rent money on cocaine last week, and missing work frequently. She denies other substance use and has no psychiatric history. Vital signs are normal, and examination shows no acute intoxication. She expresses motivation for treatment and asks about effective interventions. What is the most appropriate initial recommendation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used for treating alcohol and opioid use disorders. Naltrexone is not effective for treating cocaine use disorder because it does not target the relevant neurotransmitter pathways involved in the drug's mechanism of action.

B) INCORRECT:

Residential detoxification is not indicated in a stable patient without withdrawal symptoms or significant comorbidities. Cocaine withdrawal typically does not require medical management, and another recommendation is more appropriate for this motivated patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is used for reducing cravings in smoking cessation. The role of pharmacotherapy in cocaine use disorder is not well established and remains under investigation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Cognitive behavioral therapy is an evidence-based treatment approach for cocaine use disorder. Another approach that has shown promise is voucher-based reward therapy, a type of contingency management therapy in which patients receive rewards for reaching abstinence milestones.

E) INCORRECT:

Topiramate has been investigated for various substance use disorders, but its efficacy for treating cocaine use disorder has not been established. The role of pharmacotherapy in cocaine use disorder remains under investigation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with agitation and erratic behavior that began 3 hours ago. He exhibits paranoid ideation, reports feeling detached from his body, and describes visual distortions. Vital signs show tachycardia, hypertension, and hyperthermia. Physical examination shows mydriasis, diaphoresis, and tremor. He becomes increasingly combative during the evaluation, and physical restraints are required. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose. This patient's presentation with mydriasis, tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, and hypervigilant agitation is inconsistent with opioid intoxication, which typically causes miosis, respiratory depression, and sedation.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is used for certain types of anxiety and cardiovascular conditions, but it plays no role in the management of hallucinogen intoxication.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with classic features of hallucinogen intoxication, including paranoid ideation, depersonalization, visual distortions, and sympathomimetic effects. The most appropriate management for acute agitation in hallucinogen intoxication is supportive care with benzodiazepines. Benzodiazepines effectively control agitation while also helping to manage hyperadrenergic symptoms. Antipsychotics may also be used to address substance-induced psychosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiamine is used in the management of altered mental status if nutritional deficiencies are suspected. Thiamine plays no role in the management of hallucinogen intoxication.

E) INCORRECT:

Although ketamine may be used for severe agitation in some clinical scenarios, another agent is recommended first in the treatment of agitation in hallucinogen intoxication.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with agitation and confusion after attending a party. Vital signs are BP, 165/95; P, 125; R, 28; T, 39.8°C (103.6°F). Physical examination shows dilated pupils, diaphoresis, hyperreflexia, and intermittent clonus. Laboratory values include sodium 122 mEq/L, creatinine 1.8 mg/dL, and creatine kinase (CK) 8500 U/L. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with moderate serotonin syndrome (hyperthermia, altered mental status, hyperreflexia, and clonus). Elevated CK levels indicate rhabdomyolysis from excessive muscle activity. First-line treatment includes cyproheptadine, a 5-HT2A receptor antagonist, combined with active cooling measures to rapidly reduce temperature and prevent further complications. This patient also requires treatment for hyponatremia and benzodiazepines for agitation and increased muscle activity.

B) INCORRECT:

Flumazenil is a competitive GABA receptor antagonist used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose. Benzodiazepines are used to treat agitation and excessive muscle activity in serotonin syndrome, making flumazenil counterproductive.

C) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is not effective for serotonin syndrome and should be avoided. While patients with severe serotonin syndrome may require intubation, this patient's temperature is below 41.1°C (106°F), which is the threshold for considering sedation, paralysis, and intubation.

D) INCORRECT:

Physical restraints should be avoided in serotonin syndrome as they can worsen hyperthermia and lactic acidosis. Haloperidol may potentially worsen symptoms and does not address the underlying serotonergic overactivity.

E) INCORRECT:

Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as an antidote for pure anticholinergic poisoning. However, this patient has hyperreflexia and clonus, not hyporeflexia, indicating serotonin syndrome rather than anticholinergic poisoning.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with insomnia, restlessness, and muscle aches that began 18 hours ago. The patient reports daily cocaine use for 8 months and heroin use 3–4 times per week for the past year; last heroin use was 20 hours ago. Vital signs are BP, 145/90; P, 102; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows dilated pupils, mild diaphoresis, and rhinorrhea. The patient expresses strong motivation for treatment and asks about therapy options. What is the most appropriate initial approach?

choices.text: Naltrexone for both substance use disorders
Prescription stimulants for cocaine use disorder

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naltrexone requires 7–14 days of complete opioid abstinence before initiation to avoid precipitated withdrawal. This patient used heroin 20 hours ago, making naltrexone inappropriate at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

The role of pharmacological treatment for cocaine use disorder, including long-term prescription stimulants, is still being investigated; there is currently no established pharmacological treatment regimen. Most pharmacological treatments for cocaine use disorder have poor success rates, and psychotherapy with group programs remains the primary evidence-based approach.

C) INCORRECT:

While psychotherapy is appropriate for cocaine use disorder, this patient also has opioid use disorder, which benefits significantly from medication-assisted treatment. Psychotherapy alone would not adequately address the opioid component.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Methadone can be initiated based on subjective symptoms of opioid withdrawal. This patient's symptoms (muscle aches, insomnia, restlessness) occurred 2 hours after their last heroin use, suggesting early opioid withdrawal. Cocaine use disorder is addressed with psychotherapy and support programs, as there is currently no established pharmacological treatment regimen.

E) INCORRECT:

Clonidine provides symptomatic relief but does not address the underlying opioid use disorder. Medication-assisted treatment with opioid agonists is superior to symptomatic management alone and should be prioritized in motivated patients.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police because of agitation and impaired cognition. He was hit in the head at a local bar after starting a fight. He smells like alcohol. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Neurologic examination shows miosis and nystagmus. During the physical examination, the patient tries to attack the nursing team. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Ingestion of which of the following substances most likely explains this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Phencyclidine (PCP) ingestion is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. PCP intoxication can cause a wide variety of signs and symptoms, including vertical or horizontal nystagmus (most common symptom in overdose), increased pain tolerance, agitation, hallucinations, ataxia, amnesia, and seizures. PCP also causes miosis, which differentiates it from intoxication due to cocaine or methamphetamine (which commonly cause dilated pupils). A common complication of PCP use is trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol use disorder is very common, with a peak incidence in young adults. Intoxication with alcohol can cause impaired cognition, disinhibited behavior, nystagmus, and mild tachycardia. However, alcohol causes respiratory depression, not tachypnea, and does not cause miosis. This patient also lacks other typical manifestations of alcohol intoxication, such as slurred speech and impaired coordination. Given the alcohol smell noted on this patient, it is likely that he has recently consumed an alcoholic beverage; however, a different substance better accounts for his entire constellation of symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Intoxication with methamphetamine, a sympathomimetic drug, causes tachycardia, hypertension, and, in some cases, violent behavior. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of methamphetamine intoxication, such as psychosis (typically euphoria, grandiosity), diaphoresis, bruxism, and mydriasis (not miosis), which makes ingestion of this substance unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Heroin intoxication can cause altered mental status and miosis. However, it most commonly induces respiratory depression, bradycardia, and hypotension; the opposite features are seen in this patient. In addition, nystagmus is not a feature of heroin intoxication. Withdrawal from opiates can cause hypertension, tachycardia, and mydriasis (not miosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Cocaine intoxication can cause tachycardia, hypertension, and agitation. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of cocaine intoxication, such as nausea, diaphoresis, and chest pain. In addition, cocaine use causes mydriasis (not miosis) and does not cause nystagmus.
questions.hint: This drug primarily works via activation of dopaminergic neurons and NMDA antagonism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. He asks for advice about smoking cessation, as his past attempts were unsuccessful due to intense cravings. The provider prescribes a drug that acts as a partial agonist at the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naltrexone is a long-acting opioid receptor antagonist that is used to manage withdrawal symptoms of acute opioid detoxification and to curb the amount and frequency of drinking in alcohol dependence. Naltrexone is not an effective therapy for smoking cessation.

B) CORRECT:

Varenicline is a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor partial agonist that is used to treat nicotine dependence. The drug's partial agonism of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor produces a modified dopaminergic response, in contrast to the full dopaminergic outflow to the nucleus accumbens that nicotine binding produces. Varenicline thus reduces the rewarding effects of nicotine and minimizes cravings associated with withdrawal.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is used for the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD), generalized anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and bulimia. Fluoxetine is not an effective therapy for smoking cessation.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotine gum is a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), which is the first-line treatment for nicotine dependence to reduce smoking. For patients who want to stop smoking, NRT provides nicotine, thereby reducing withdrawal symptoms. The active substance in nicotine gum, however, is a full nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonist, unlike the drug prescribed to this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Bupropion is a norepinephrine and dopamine uptake inhibitor that can be used for smoking cessation. Although it reduces the withdrawal and craving effects of smoking cessation, bupropion does not act on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, unlike the drug prescribed to this patient.
questions.hint: The adverse effects of this drug, which is used exclusively as a smoking cessation aid, include nausea, headache, and sleep disturbances.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate because of a 2-hour history of increased thirst and erratic behavior. The roommate says that the patient returned home from a party and began to touch pillows and blankets in the apartment and profess her intensely positive feelings and affection for the world. The roommate also reports that the patient often uses recreational drugs at parties. On arrival, the patient is diaphoretic and oriented only to person. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 156/102 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows tremulousness and bilateral pupillary dilation. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 130 mEq/L. This patient is most likely intoxicated with which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients intoxicated with lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) classically present with vivid visual hallucinations and distorted time perception, but can also experience anxiety, agitation, and paranoid delusions. In addition, LSD has mild sympathomimetic effects such as tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. However, increased thirst, hyperthermia, tremor, and hyponatremia are not features consistent with LSD intoxication.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's increased thirst, euphoria, confusion, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis, tremor, and hyponatremia indicate intoxication with 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA). MDMA-induced hyponatremia is due to an inappropriate increase in ADH, increased thirst stimulation, and the belief of some users that the intake of large amounts of water can help prevent hyperthermia. The treatment of MDMA intoxication focuses on controlling the patient's hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, and hyponatremia. Mild hyponatremia can be treated with fluid restriction. If the patient develops severe hyponatremia with neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, confusion), hypertonic saline is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication can also manifest with confusion, euphoria, hyperthermia, tachycardia, and hypertension. However, PCP typically causes miosis, not mydriasis, and is inconsistent with this patient's increased thirst and hyponatremia. Moreover, aggressive behavior and nystagmus would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with cocaine intoxication can present with confusion, euphoria, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, tremor, and bilateral mydriasis. However, it would not explain this patient's increased thirst and hyponatremia.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitrous oxide intoxication can also manifest with confusion, euphoria, and tremor. However, hypertension, tachycardia, increased body temperature, diaphoresis, increased thirst, and hyponatremia would not be expected. Moreover, nitrous oxide has a short duration of action and the symptoms are unlikely to persist for this long.
questions.hint: Overdose with this drug can also cause serotonin syndrome.
